text: What is already known about this topic? Anxiety and discomfort related to the need to self-inject epinephrine in an emergency contributes to food-allergic adolescents' occasional failure to use an autoinjector, and may increase their risk when an anaphylactic reaction occurs. What does this article add to our knowledge? A supervised self-injection procedure with an empty syringe improved adolescents' comfort with self-injection, and decreased anxiety related to the anticipated need to self-inject. How does this study impact current management guidelines? A simple self-injection procedure (needle and empty syringe) in addition to standard training is beneficial for adolescents with food allergy who are willing to perform this maneuver. BACKGROUND: Epinephrine self-injection is a key element in the management of food allergy, yet many adolescents report that they may not be able to use the autoinjector when needed. We hypothesized that supervised self-injection with an empty syringe would increase adolescents' comfort with self-injection. OBJECTIVE: The objective of this study was to examine the effect of supervised self-injection on self-and parent-reported comfort and anxiety during and after clinic visits in a food allergy center. METHODS: Sixty adolescent/parent pairs were randomized to self-injection versus control (education only). The predefined primary outcome was a self-reported comfort level with the injection before versus after the intervention on a Likert scale with scores of 1 (Not at all comfortable) to 10 (Extremely comfortable). The primary outcome was evaluated via withingroup and between-group analyses. Secondary outcomes included adolescent and parent reports before versus after the injection, and changes in quality of life (QoL) and anxiety a month later. RESULTS: Self-injection was associated with a significant immediate increase in comfort levels (primary outcome; withingroup comparison: mean scores: 6.93 preintervention vs 8.37 postintervention, P < .01; between-group ANOVA: 8.37 vs 6.69, P < .01) and with significant improvements in all other predefined (secondary) measures. On follow-up, QoL improved in 52% of intervention patients as compared with 25% of controls; similar differences were observed for anxiety. Those differences were not statistically significant. CONCLUSIONS: A self-injection (with an empty syringe) procedure in a clinic setting improves adolescents' and parents' comfort level with self-injecting. It may translate into substantial clinical benefits should self-injection be needed.

text: QoL-Quality of Life SCARED-Screen for Child Anxiety-Related Emotional Disorders is recommended that all patients who experienced anaphylaxis, and those with food allergy and asthma and/or known allergy to potent triggers such as peanut, tree nuts, fish, or shellfish, should be prescribed self-injectable epinephrine. 4, 5 Unfortunately, adolescents are at higher risk for fatal food-allergic reactions in part because of reluctance to self-inject epinephrine. [6] [7] [8] Our previous studies found that adolescents who become increasingly responsible for their own care are at risk for not carrying the self-injector. 9 We also found that patients with food allergy report substantial levels of anxiety related to the food allergy, and (anecdotally) that they are nervous about the prospect of having to use the autoinjector to inject themselves with epinephrine, should the need arise. It appears therefore that anxiety about the injection interferes with the development of appropriate food allergy self-management skills. We also found that patients who used the autoinjector in the past were not more anxious later on, 10 which strongly suggests that future anxiety would not be increased, and perhaps even be decreased, by guided self-injection. Indeed, investigators demonstrated that guidance offered on the use of an autoinjector in a clinic setting could be helpful in increasing parent confidence. 11 It would therefore be important to identify a means to improve comfort with selfinjection for adolescents as a part of routine clinical education.

text: We conducted a prospective, randomized controlled trial in which food-allergic adolescents who did not previously use an autoinjector were randomized into an "education-only" versus "self-injection" groups in a pediatric food allergy clinic in New York (ClinicalTrials.Gov registration: NCT02417493). The primary outcome chosen is the difference in patient-reported comfort with injection in the clinic pre-post intervention, which was evaluated via within-group and between-group analyses. The in-clinic assessment was chosen as a primary outcome because it most closely mimics the anxiety that might occur during an allergic reaction, as opposed to scores obtained at home, long after the injection, in a relaxed setting. We also predefined a set of secondary outcomes that evaluate the degree to which patients or parents report that the patients will be comfortable using the self-injector in the future when needed, both before versus after the intervention, and at follow-up (questionnaires were sent to families a month after the intervention). Exploratory analyses included assessment of the evolution of quality of life (QoL) (adolescent report) and anxiety (parent report of the adolescent's anxiety and adolescent selfreport) between the immediate postinjection period and follow-up in the control versus the intervention groups.

The study was approved by the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai's Institutional Review Board and involved a full written parental consent and child assent procedure.

text: After the consent procedure, before randomization, patients and parents were asked to complete self-report questionnaires about their (or their child's) comfort with self-injection. Then, half of the sample (n ¼ 30) was randomized to the intervention (self-injection group) and the other half (n ¼ 30) was randomized to the control condition (standard education, control group), by research assistants' pulling a number out of a sealed envelope. Intervention group participants answered a set of questionnaires on the same day immediately after the injection, and control patients answered the same set of questionnaires on the same day, after the education was given. One month after the clinic visit, participants and their parents were mailed a follow-up questionnaire packet that was identical to that completed by the participant and parent on the day of recruitment. Patients who did not send the packet back within a week were called twice to remind them to send it.

text: The primary analytic strategy involved a repeated-measure (prepost) analysis of the primary outcome in the intervention group (below); a secondary analysis of the primary outcome involved a between-group analysis. For the repeated measures analysis, we determined that to detect a medium effect size (using Cohen's definitions 14 operationalized with a G*Power software 15 ), we would need 34 unique tests (pre-post information on 17 subjects). We assumed a substantial level of attrition because we were concerned that some patients would decline to answer the questionnaires immediately after the injection if they became upset or distressed. On the basis of our previous study in a similar sample, that recorded 40% to 50% failure to complete repeated-measures procedures, 16 we determined that a final recruitment goal of n ¼ 30 in each group, after attrition, would provide the required number of subjects to detect a small-to-medium effect size for both the primary and secondary analytic strategies of the primary outcome.

text: Participants watched while a sterile 25-gauge needle was mounted on an empty 5 cc syringe, with the plunger pushed down to expel any air. The participant's leg was uncovered and precleaned with alcohol. The participant was coached how to hold the syringe firmly in the fist, put the point of the needle very near the skin, and gently insert the needle at a 90 angle through the skin overlying the anterolateral thigh. On completion, the syringe was disposed of securely. In cases in which the participant was reluctant to inject, the parents and researchers were allowed to verbally coach and encourage injection, but without coercion. We expected that in some cases, adolescents would not be able to self-inject (would ultimately refuse, even if they agreed to participate in the study).

text: All analyses were conducted using the IBM SPSS 20.0 statistical package. For the primary and secondary analyses, 2-tailed pairedsamples t-tests were conducted to investigate immediate post minus immediate preintervention (or education) scores. Analyses of variance were conducted to assess between-group comparisons. Exploratory comparisons between control and intervention group follow-up QoL and anxiety measures primarily investigated the number of people who reported improvement/worsening/no change, to minimize the effect of outliers; means were also computed for a between-group analysis of the difference in 1-month exploratory (SCARED and QOL) outcomes. A P value (alpha level) of less than .05, 2-tailed, was chosen as the level of statistical significance. All analyses presented were predefined before the study commenced. Figure 1 is a Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials (CONSORT) diagram reflecting the recruitment efforts. Of 124 patients who were assessed, deemed eligible to participate, and approached for the study, 60 patients (48%) enrolled. Demographic information is presented in Table I . There were no differences between conditions.

text: We evaluated the potential benefit of a simple self-injection procedure for improving food-allergic adolescents' comfort with autoinjectors. Our primary outcome measure, a pre-post evaluation immediately after the injection, is not subject to recall bias as it was assessed immediately after the event. The procedure was beneficial as determined by a statistically significant improvement in the adolescents' self-reported comfort with self-injection (our predefined primary endpoint) both in within-subject and between-subject analyses, with a large effect size, and as further demonstrated by multiple additional indicators. The nonsignificant improvements in QoL and anxiety observed between the immediate postinjection period and follow-up are encouraging. The effects of an intervention that is specifically targeting subject's feeling at the time of an urgent event (the need to autoinject) may not be apparent in the absence of such an event. Therefore, the signal that the procedure may have generalized into an improvement even in the safety of one's home on followup is a positive sign, but we caution that we were unable to investigate whether intervention patients who undergo this procedure are, in fact, able to use the autoinjector more easily or accurately when needed. The study was not designed to evaluate responses during a true anaphylactic emergency given the rarity of such events. Such a study would require extremely large numbers of patients followed over years. Our results show that patients are less anxious about self-injecting and more comfortable with it. In addition, although the intervention effect size was large, the minimal clinical effect threshold for some of the instruments is not known, and therefore a larger and longer investigation would need to be conducted to prove that the benefits that we saw translate into lasting clinical benefits. Imaginal or gradual exposure to a stressor is a hallmark of cognitive-behavioral procedures that were shown to be effective in the treatment of phobias 12 and anxiety disorders. 24, 25 Our approach has important features of these well-accepted approaches in that we exposed subjects to a simulation of the very circumstance that they may fear. In other settings, exposure techniques were shown to reduce avoidance behaviors and improve adherence to medical recommendations. 26, 27 In the food-allergy setting, this may translate into a higher likelihood of using the autoinjector when indicated; epinephrine administered by intramuscular self-injectors is safe and generally well tolerated. 28 Anecdotally, investigators in our study reported that the most anxious patients, who were reluctant to participate in the trial at first, were also those who showed the most benefit, but our study was not designed to evaluate which patients would benefit the most. Our study was limited by the fact that the procedure, by necessity, was not masked, and by a likely selection bias. Because of the requirement for patient assent (not only parent consent), only subjects who agreed to the procedure were enrolled, likely resulting in exclusion of the most anxious patients or parents. Indeed, we have observed instances in which the adolescent would not provide assent despite parental consent. It could be that anxious patients might have been even more likely to benefit from the procedure. Alternatively, it could also be that very anxious patients, who might have been excluded by the required assent process, would not have benefitted if enrolled. The correct interpretation of our results is that the procedure can be helpful for adolescents who agree to do it. Another source of potential selection bias is the fact that the majority, but not all, of the patients returned the follow-up questionnaires. It could be that the observed sustained improvements in QoL and anxiety are because only those patients who improved returned the questionnaires. This is unlikely, however, because almost as many control subjects returned the follow-up questionnaire as intervention subjects (21 controls vs 24 intervention). Finally, our results are further limited by the fact that the procedure was offered in one specialized center with a specific patient characteristic profile-mainly white, highly educated, and high-income parents. A larger study incorporating measures of actual adherence (likelihood of carrying an autoinjector after the procedure, for example) is needed to conclusively prove a lasting clinical benefit.

Our primary outcome measure, a pre-post evaluation immediately after the injection, is not subject to recall bias as it was assessed immediately after the event.

The procedure was beneficial as determined by a statistically significant improvement in the adolescents' self-reported comfort with self-injection (our predefined primary endpoint) both in within-subject and between-subject analyses, with a large effect size, and as further demonstrated by multiple additional indicators.
The nonsignificant improvements in QoL and anxiety observed between the immediate postinjection period and follow-up are encouraging.
The effects of an intervention that is specifically targeting subject's feeling at the time of an urgent event (the need to autoinject) may not be apparent in the absence of such an event.

Therefore, the signal that the procedure may have generalized into an improvement even in the safety of one's home on followup is a positive sign, but we caution that we were unable to investigate whether intervention patients who undergo this procedure are, in fact, able to use the autoinjector more easily or accurately when needed.
The study was not designed to evaluate responses during a true anaphylactic emergency given the rarity of such events.
Such a study would require extremely large numbers of patients followed over years.
Our results show that patients are less anxious about self-injecting and more comfortable with it.

In addition, although the intervention effect size was large, the minimal clinical effect threshold for some of the instruments is not known, and therefore a larger and longer investigation would need to be conducted to prove that the benefits that we saw translate into lasting clinical benefits.
Imaginal or gradual exposure to a stressor is a hallmark of cognitive-behavioral procedures that were shown to be effective in the treatment of phobias 12 and anxiety disorders.

text: Our study showed that self-injection with a needle (without epinephrine) in the office setting improved comfort with selfinjection and was well received. We did not have access to a sham autoinjector with an actual needle as this kind of device is not currently being manufactured, and therefore used a simple needle, which is available in any clinic. A sham autoinjector, if it becomes available, might have been an even better simulator. As it stands, our intervention could be offered in select clinical circumstances (eg, when adolescents and parents agree; when the adolescent seems to be anxious about the prospect of needing an injection). This simple, quick, behavioral intervention is easy to deliver, does not require special expertise, and may result in improved QoL and attendant clinical benefits. 3.
